content.description: Gambling disorder is a persistent and recurrent problematic gambling behavior leading to clinically significant impairment or distress. Although not involving a psychoactive substance, it shares features with substance use disorders, including tolerance, withdrawal, and compulsive engagement despite negative consequences.

mechanisms: Dysregulation of the brain's reward circuitry, particularly the mesolimbic dopamine pathway (ventral tegmental area to nucleus accumbens).
Altered activity in the prefrontal cortex affecting impulse control and decision-making.
Heightened sensitivity to reward cues and diminished sensitivity to losses.

content.diagnostic_criteria: Persistent and recurrent problematic gambling behavior, as indicated by ≥4 of the following in a 12-month period: needs to gamble with increasing amounts of money to achieve excitement; restless/irritable when attempting to cut down; repeated unsuccessful efforts to control/cut back/stop; preoccupied with gambling; gambles when distressed; after losing money, returns to get even; lies to conceal extent; jeopardized/ lost relationships, job, or education; relies on others for money to relieve financial situation. Not better explained by a manic episode.
content.prevalence: Lifetime prevalence ~0.4–1% in the U.S., with higher rates among men and younger adults.
content.age_of_onset: Typically begins in adolescence or early adulthood, though women may develop later with a more rapid progression.
content.prognosis: Chronic course if untreated; periods of remission may occur, but relapse is common. Better prognosis with early intervention, social support, and treatment engagement.

history: Detailed gambling behavior (types, frequency, money spent)
Attempts to cut down and triggers for gambling

biological: Family history of gambling disorder or substance use disorder
environmental: Easy access to gambling venues or online platforms

impact_on_life.financial: Debt, bankruptcy, theft to finance gambling

psychotherapy: Cognitive-behavioral therapy targeting cognitive distortions and developing alternative coping strategies
Motivational interviewing to enhance readiness for change
Group therapy and peer support (e.g., Gamblers Anonymous)
medications: SSRIs for comorbid depression or anxiety
Opioid antagonists (naltrexone, nalmefene) to reduce urges
Mood stabilizers in cases with mood lability
lifestyle_interventions: Financial counseling and money management support
care_coordination: Collaboration with legal and financial advisors
Integration with treatment for comorbid disorders

treatment_goals: Achieve and maintain abstinence from gambling
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing financial or relationship problems solely to poor budgeting or personality without assessing gambling behavior
Overlooking gambling when no substance use is present
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling occasional recreational gambling without impairment as a disorder
Confusing investment behavior with gambling when risk assessment is present
self_help_strategies: Hand over financial control to a trusted person

adolescents: Sports betting, online gaming with gambling elements, secrecy about money
adults: Casino visits, online poker, significant debt accumulation
older_adults: Increased gambling during retirement, loneliness-driven gambling

real_life_examples: A 22-year-old college student begins betting on sports daily, hiding debts from family, and skipping classes to watch games.
A 45-year-old man develops severe slot machine gambling after job loss, leading to bankruptcy and marital separation.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek professional help if gambling is causing financial hardship, relationship conflict, legal problems, or inability to stop despite wanting to.
